review_title: Impressive recruitment for an overworked and underappreciated position
job_title: Hall Director in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
- Higher salary compared to other school in the area
- Leadership Team (LT) supports creativity and encourages additional responsibilities 
- Opportunities to grow in higher education field
- ResLife has money, so LT encourages to 'dream big' for programming
cons:
- Because you are paid higher than competition, they will constantly remind you that as they keep on adding more on your plate. 
- No compassion for the countless might time meetings ending at 11pm amd I am not talking about just hall staff meetings 
- As an HD, you are expected to host programs, attend programs, manage some HR work (EPAF, work hours, pay rates, hiring/firing staff on system ), desk management, constant conflict management among staff and/or residents with zero accountability system in place, therefore conflicts and disrespect remains constant
- Leadership Team is full of 'fake niceness' and performative activism. If you can bear with those, there comes politics and favorism which heavily impacts your reputation at TCU. Weather they like you too much or too little, they will have your existence on campus unbearable once you tell them you have decided to either leave TCU or even move on to a different position on campus. Like I have never experienced a group of professional taking the decision of an HD moving away leaving so personally.
- The Leadership expects you to finish 1700 tasks in a day and then in cue with fake niceness, tells you "hey take some time for yourself, ok?"
- All ResLife staff are trained on "No work life balance rather try to practice work life blend". That turned out to be very destructive in my opinion as I was expected to work around the clock but also have a sound mental health. 
- Leadership Team members says such tone deaf things that it seems surreal that they truly work in higher education with such little empathy.
- As HDs drop like flies, instead of ADs giving proxy, remaining HDs are asked to oversee multiple buildings. Heard only a few months ago they started additional pay for multiple building coverages. Think 10-12 hours of extra work every week, when that happens.

pros: flexible, nice people and work environment
cons: time consuming but learned a lot

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Love the environment here and the professors
cons: Only real events are Greek related

review_title: The cons are beginning to outweigh the pros
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
* Fantastic benefits.
* Mostly pleasant work environment. 
* Relatively good pay for support staff (compared to other universities and colleges).
cons:
* Employees with unconventional shifts (evenings and weekends) are completely overlooked and unappreciated.
* Parking lots are inadequate for the huge number of commuters on campus, making getting around campus very difficult (especially if you have mobility issues).
* Constant construction that negatively impacts campus parking, the surrounding neighborhood, and the environment in general.
* It’s very difficult for support staff to move into other jobs on campus, even when trying to make a lateral move.

review_title: Horned Frogs make for a great job!
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Lots of fun, nice, friendly people to work with. Good benefits. The faculty are great, and the administration is pretty good. It's a university, so there are lots of great activities and classes you can attend. And tuition is free if you're full time! 
My favorite benefit is I can take off 2 hours each month that don't come out of my vacation or sick leave. It's specifically available for running errands or doctor's appointments. Awesome!
Employees are very involved, love the school, and love the students. Everyone goes to football games and wears school colors. I love it here!
cons:
Some people complain about salary. Considering it's the most I've ever made in my career so far, I'm not complaining. It is a private institution, so don't expect millions. 
Also, as with any company with a "family" feel, there can be squabbles. I don't get involved in them, so it doesn't really bother me. It does happen though. No place is perfect!

job_title: Information Technology in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Most people who work at TCU want to be there, which makes the work environment friendly and productive for the most part. The University is very focused on its core mission of teaching and learning. The Chancellor is a wonderful leader, too!
cons: The rich are getting richer: The top 15-20 earners at the University are making more and more money while compensation has been cut permanently for lower earners.

review_title: TCU is great for student or professional employees! You really can become a part of the horn frog family!
job_title: in Fort Worth, TX
pros: It was my experience that my superiors treated me with courtesy and respect, even though they were my boss or the director of of a department. There is more of a family atmosphere.
cons: While the school is working on their cultural diversity, it is still a majority of upper class Caucasian students. Not that there is anything wrong with that, but it can become a bit of a speed bump when talking about cultural acceptant.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Fort Worth, TX
pros: TCU is a collaborative and caring community that takes pride in how it treats its employees. It offers excellent vacation and benefits. One of the best things about TCU is that it's big enough to offer world-class amenities and events, but feels smaller because of the close-knit community. People often spend their entire careers here.
cons: Salaries are moderate and rarely large. TCU can be traditional, but things are changing. Like any higher Ed institution, progress can move slowly.

job_title: in Fort Worth, TX
pros: As a whole, faculty and staff are at TCU for the right reasons - they love what they do, they care about the students, and they care about each other.  Professional environment, attitude of respect for differences, and forward thinking.  The campus is beautifully maintained, and there's always something new going on.  There's so much local support from Fort Worth, in particular, and from the DFW area, that I am proud to be associated with TCU.
cons: Salaries may not be as high as in a corporate environment, but the benefits and work/life balance are outstanding!

review_title: TCU -- Come for the benefits, stay for the benefits. (Not the pay.)
job_title: in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Generous time off and holidays, good health insurance, extremely great education benefits (if you or your family members attend TCU), generally a positive place to work.
cons: Below-market pay, very limited opportunities for promotions in support fields, some facilities are a bit lacking (although they're trying), low turnover means the pace of change can be glacial.

review_title: Great institution which cares about well-being of employees
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Working in Student Affairs during a restructuring and facility enhancements did not take away from the camaraderie and cordiality among my colleagues. Very well-organized but not micro-managed, Student Affairs stood out as a very satisfied division.
cons: The students aren't all terrible, but in fact friendly and cordial. However their lack of imagination and creativity was sometimes frightening. Human Resources needs an internal audit as well.

review_title: Good, but has potential to be great
job_title: in Morgan Hill, CA
pros:
* Good employee benefits (free tuition for children,  good healthcare insurance, competitive faculty salaries) 
* Campus looks spiffy.  The grounds are under constant landscaping care and always looks attractive.  I was always proud of the way the institution presented itself when I hosted guests. 
* The university seems to have a lot of resources, and can typically "make things happen" if you can provide a good rationale for why you might need travel funds, laboratory improvements, etc. 
* In a low cost-of-living part of the country.  $200-$250K  can still buy a decent house with a lot of land (depending on how far you are willing to commute)
* Ft Worth/Dallas area is a nice place to live; real culture in the downtown areas (art, theater, etc), lots of things to do
cons:
* The business school, athletics and one or two other programs were clearly the priority of the university, as demonstrated by the attention they received, the resources invested, and the new tenure lines they were provided.  Other schools within the university knew where they fell within that hierarchy. 
* Philosophically speaking, the university seems to think of itself more as a business than as a higher institute of learning.  Real education requires holding students accountable to performance standards, not just giving everyone a gold star for effort to insure they are happy "customers".  I would have been a happier faculty member, had I felt that the university shared this point of view.  
* As a new faculty member coming in with fresh perspectives/ideas, it was very difficult to effect positive change that involved challenging the effectiveness of old and possibly outdated approaches. 
* the lack of diversity within certain departments is unfortunate
* was discouraged by university not pushing harder on faculty to apply for and get external funding to supplement their research activities.  I was diligent about seeking grants while many of my colleagues just stuck their hand out to the university when they needed funds to support research.  This sense of entitlement seemed to be endemic across the campus, as I saw this attitude present beyond my own department.

job_title: Coordinator in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The benefits are amazing at TCU. The tuition benefit is hard to beat. The culture at TCU is super people-oriented, which I really like. TCU really takes care of its employees.
cons: There aren't many downsides to working at TCU. If you're coming to TCU from a state university with strict rules, hierarchies, and bureaucracy, you may struggle to adapt to the more fluid people-oriented culture.

review_title: Amazing university culture and spirit! Great place to work!
job_title: Learning Assistant In the AASO in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Best place on earth. Great work environment for all positions. Loving and caring student body as well as administration. You can sense the feeling of, "We are all in this together." Great benefits. They will match up to 11% of your salary for your 401(k) after you have worked there for two years. You also get benefits such as the ability to pursue a degree while working there. You can take up to 6 semester hours per semester.
cons: I honestly cannot think of one con!

job_title: Computer Support Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
cons: Sometimes, it could take a while to move to a permanent position; otherwise, it is one of the best places to work.

job_title: Acquisitions Assistant in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
-Flexible hours
-Nice staff
-Easy job to balance with school work
-They let you listen to music while working
cons:
-Very boring and repetitive job
-Workers are so shy that it is difficult to feel at home at first
-When things got slow and there was no work to do they do not let you leave early

job_title: Development Representative in Friendswood, TX
pros: Working at TCU provided flexible hours for students while also allowing near full time employment if desired. Also the supervisors provided guidance and assistance whenever needed.
cons: One of the Cons of working at this TCU position was the lack of structure at times in the office environment. Also the pay was not as high as one could hope for when aquiring large donations for the school

review_title: Challenging, and fruitful in benefits of family, fun, and my future.
job_title: Resident Assistant in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Able to work within parameters of field without major interjection as to how to complete tasks, ability to maintain flexible work schedules, opportunities to dip into multiple experience venues
cons: Slightly less structured for individuals who are looking for a hierarchical-driven system; though advancement exists it is not the only path. Opportunity is not always given, so be sure to seek it as much as you desire it

review_title: Used to be a good place to work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: What's not to love about being a Frog! The people are wonderful-- people who work at TCU love the school and love their jobs. Lots of educational opportunities available on campus, plus discount athletics tickets, discount theater tickets and tuition benefit.
cons: Executives operate on reactive mode instead of proactive. Many decisions based on who gets to the Chancellor first and employees not supported when trying to do their jobs. Employees blamed for poor decisions of managers.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Fort Worth, TX
pros: TCU is a very people centered organization. They focus on building connection between students and faculty that drive career success.
cons: Most students tend to be upper class, although there is a full range of students from all economic classes. This can create certain cultural expectations in social groups.

review_title: Monitors the office and corresponds with clients
job_title: Office Administrator in Fort Worth, TX
pros: A really great boss who is a TCU alumni and understands what her employees are going through with school work and life. Also, the working environment is really creative, open, and innovative.
cons: The salary is ok for it is a student sales office. Also, at times the office can be more fun. But overall, for a sales office, it is comfortable enough to work for.

job_title: Writing Associate in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Decent pay, good experience as an educator, great managers and the potential to work a lot of hours.  You get out of the job what you put in.
cons: This program is apparently being shut down, so I don't know if it will be replaced by a similar program.

job_title: Web Services Manager in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Excellent benefits for faculty and staff: medical insurance, retirement account, tuition benefit for employee and family members. Friendly staff to work with, excellent library, great team spirit. Generous holidays.
cons: Salary on the lower end.  For classified staff, some departments have lower chances for advancement so there is a tendency for staff who want to remain at TCU to move from department to department for a better paying position.

job_title: in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Family focused environment, wanting the best for the students, the university, and the city. TCU's campus is beautiful! They are a very proud community, and they should be!
cons: Currently in a long-term hiring free for staff positions, adding faculty but no support. Makes it difficult to be productive when short staffed.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The campus is lovely and the people are friendly. There are many opportunities for professional development.
cons: Perhaps full faculty and staff have a different  experience, but I am an adjunct with little possibility to advancement and no benefits.

job_title: in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Got to know great people who could help with networking and learning opportunities and enjoyed working with people so often.
cons: Working in an academic setting is very enjoyable, I really didn't find any cons to working here and would recommend it to anyone.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Gives an opportunity to get better at public speaking, as well as gives an opportunity to try to get students engaged and interested in a subject they might not find fascinating at first.
cons: The only con is that teaching labs and grading labs often interferes with studying and doing research, but as long as you manage time well it is not an issue.

job_title: IT Staff in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Like being part of a big family. Great benefits especially if you have children that would benefit from free tuition.
cons: Hey, it's academia with its politics. They rarely fire anyone so you have some people that have been here decades but don't do much.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Exciting atmosphere and great people. Professional development is a top priority for this school. The students are great and the funding for programs just keeps appearing.
cons: You wait two years for retirement to kick in. They have their favorites and they make it known. You really need to enjoy the heat to work in TX.

review_title: Adjunct professorship allows for great freedom with pittance wages
job_title: Adjunct Professor; Graduate Student in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Technology is up-to-date and reliable and there is fantastic freedom within the classroom to teach however you see fit.
cons: The pay is low (for graduate students teaching courses) and the focus is on satisfying undergraduate students and somewhat less on teaching them.

job_title: Intramural Referee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Great people, atmosphere, and a lot of fun refing games. Schedule is flexible and every year you ref you get a $0.25 raise
cons: No one will ever take a shift, usually have to offer $20 or more to someone if an emergency comes up.

job_title: Marketing Intern in Fort Worth, TX
pros: You get to make your own schedule around when you are available. You get a lot of hands on experience in athletics marketing. Everyone is super helpful and amazing to work with.

pros: The atmosphere is excellent, and the professors and academic staff are beyond helpful, wise, and endearing. You learn a lot and meet a number of great people.
cons: The work load was at times overwhelming, but the staff is very considerable of your studies and work life balance.

job_title: Student Worker in Fort Worth, TX

Everyone is friendly. Someone will always greet you with a smile. 
Family oriented community. 
Training is always accessible. There are seminars within departments.
cons: If you don't want to be around college students, I would suggest not working at a university. Hours are strict... pretty much 9-5.

job_title: Peer Coach At Neeley Professional Development Center in Fort Worth, TX
